Posts.Content: Michael, The pain was their fault and mine .. First, they didn't numb the area enough. I felt the first staple and the pain was unbelievable. It didn't get any better...five more staples and they were done. Then the nurse removed the catheter when she should have left it in. You have to pass urine prior to them removing the catheter. I was passing blood, not urine. The blood coagulated, blocking all urine from leaving my body. I figured not being able to urinate was normal for the first couple days...man, I was wrong. This went on for 5 days before I called the doctor. A quick trip to the emergency room and a new catheter all pain was gone. About a week later the catheter was removed and things have been great ever since. I would do it again if I needed it. I would just make sure they knocked me out.
Posts.Title: AS checkup

Posts.Content: Haven't been on the forum in a while. It's time for my AS 6 month checkup. Everything seems to be fine. Just got my labs back and I don't understand how to read the free and total PSA. If anyone understand's thsee readings please explain. PSA. 2.04 PSA, FREE 0.37 PSA, TOTAL 2.3 I had the UroLift procedure about 4 months ago for my enlarged prostrate. The procedure was one of the most painful things I ever felt. Followed by two weeks of a catheter. Finally everything is working fine. No more getting up 4 or 5 times a night....only once.

Posts.Title: AS checkup

Posts.Content: Brownie, I also have used the VA system and have been diagnosed with two different things due to Agent Orange. I have only used the VA for my meds. Once the Choice doctor writes a prescription I give it to my VA PCP He fills it through the VA pharmacy...no questions asked. I have never had to follow any "game plan" from the VA. You can insist on what treatment plan you want use....after all its your body. Another thing...PC is a 100% rating so there is no charge to you from the VA or Choice Program for meds. and if you have ED there is an additional rating.

Malignant Neoplasm of Prostate 2. Hormone Sensitive Malignancy Status 3. Asymptomatic Microscopic Hematuria
Posts.Title: VA vs University Medical

Posts.Content: Brownie, I can only tell you about my experience with the VA. My PCP is great and in the last 3 years has always referred me to outside doctors. I was referred one time to VA urology and I refused treatment. I wouldn't even let them do a DRE. Within 2 weeks I was at an outside specialist. I did use the head of the VA urology department for a second opinion. They recommend RP (always). I was told they just want to cut the cancer out. As far as your PSA level and still being 100%. You will continue to be 100% as long as you have PC. PSA levels mean nothing (to the VA)..my PSA is only 1.81. After 6 months of treatment (radiation/surgery/whatever) they will reevaluate you, then rate whatever side effects you may have. If you still have PC you will continue the 100% plus any special ratings for side effects. Joe's right about mixing Medical with Choice/VA. I think you'll end up with a large bill. Remember to be assertive with your VA doctors....know one cares more about your health that you. If the VA gives you any static go to the patient advocate office. Best of luck, Dog

Posts.Content: Today I was able to get my second opinion from a urologist out of UC San Diego. I was hoping for something a little more positive. After reviewing my biopsy she doesn't agree with my urologist and doesn't believe I'm an AS candidate. She does agree I should wait for the Polaris results (hopefully Friday) before deciding.

Posts.Content: Denis, Thanks for the encouraging words. Most on this site jump to some type of intervention, seems like very few believe in AS. I, like you, can live with knowing cancer is inside my body. The "guide lines" for AS seems to vary depending on which study you read. Again I like you might have to change my decision after my Polaris / Genomic testing results. Diesel

Posts.Content: Denis, Thanks for all the information. You mentioned the man who waited 7 years before intervention. That's my hope with AS. If I ever need intervention there will be advances that will help me advoid the drawbacks of the current procedurs. I couldn't imagine proceeding with AS without Polaris or some other testing. The problem is it seems to take so long for the results. It's been 25 days (15 work days) since my samples were sent for testing....Seems like months. Maybe next convention I'll tag along. Take care, Diesel

Posts.Content: In regards to diet you said meat was out. Although I rarely eat meat I'm curious as to why others have given it up. Does it have anything to do with all the chemicals/steroids pumped into the livestock? My diet consists of chicken, fish, brown rice, some vegetables, and fruit. Being new in the world of PC I want to make sure I'm eating the right things.

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: HI all, I'm new to the forum and to cancer. A little bit about myself. I'm 66, fairly healthy, and have no symptoms. In Dec 2016 at a "routine" doctors appointment my blood test showed elevated red blood cells and trace blood in my urine. My doctor assured me (after a CT scan) I just had a small cyst in my kidney and it was nothing to worry about. I wasn't happy with my doctor's evaluation so I started digging into my medical records. I found my PSA went from .07 to 2.54 in 6 months. I then went to a Urologist who discovered I had a enlarged prostrate. Making a long story short after a biopsy(2 week's ago) my Gleason scores are three 6's and one 7. I decided AS was the right thing for me. My doctor did send my specimen out for Polaris testing . Maybe that'll change things. So, after all that I guess I'm here for support, guidance, or whatever. Thanks all for taking the time to read this.
Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks all for the advice and encouragement. As for the AS plan monthly PSA testing and another biopsy in 6 months. If the Polaris testing comes back showing an aggressive cancer we'll go with surgery. Here are my numbers: Gleason scores 6 (3+3) at about 10% of the specimen 6 (3+3) at about 20% of the specimen 6 (3+3) at about 3% of the specimen 7 (3+4) at about 10% of the specimen

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: In regards to diet you said meat was out. Although I rarely eat meat I'm curious as to why others have given it up. Does it have anything to do with all the chemicals/steroids pumped into the livestock? My diet consists of chicken, fish, brown rice, some vegetables, and fruit. Being new in the world of PC I want to make sure I'm eating the right things.

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Finally got my Polaris test back. They rated my PC at a 3.3 consistent & prostate cancer specific. It showed a mortality risk: 2.3% at 10 years with no intervention and a metastasis risk under 1.0% at 10 years. Also a mortality rate at 2.7% at 15 years with no intervention and a metastasis rate of 1.3% at 15 years. My doctor still believes I'm a good candidate for AS and I'm in agreement. Last PSA 1.41. Of course we'll do all the quarterly, semi-annual, and annual test and check ups. I can breath a little easier.

Posts.Title: Urolift

Posts.Content: Thanks all for the advice and encouragement. As for the AS plan monthly PSA testing and another biopsy in 6 months. If the Polaris testing comes back showing an aggressive cancer we'll go with surgery. Here are my numbers: Gleason scores 6 (3+3) at about 10% of the specimen 6 (3+3) at about 20% of the specimen 6 (3+3) at about 3% of the specimen 7 (3+4) at about 10% of the specimen
Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: When I spoke to my doctor I asked him if he or his son were in my position what would he do. His reply was AS. Mainly because my 7 was 3+4.
Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: When I spoke to my doctor I asked him if he or his son were in my position what would he do. His reply was AS. Mainly because my 7 was 3+4.
Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: Greeting All, Another question for my brothers : Due to my enlarged prostrate I'm having a very difficult time "going". Most of the time the urgency is nothing but a few drops and starting takes forever. Also, there's the fun of getting up 3 or 4 times a night to try and urinate. My urologist has recommended a procedure call "Urolife". I wanted to know if anyone can tell me if the procedure is worth it. Again, thanks to all. D.

Posts.Title: Psa + t = pc

Posts.Content: Being new to PC I have so many questions. Hopefully this question isn't to dumb. Everything I've read talks about elevated PSA and how Testosterone feeds PC. Can someone explain how low T and low PSA equal PC. My T is naturally low, currently 280 and My PSA has never been over 2.51 (currently 1.81). Thanks all, Diesel
